title: Two functions of y and polar area part - d

content.description: The figure above shows the graphs of the line <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mfrac> <mn>5</mn> <mn>3</mn> </mfrac> <mi>y</mi> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3DE7@</annotation> </semantics> </math> and the curve C given by <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> <mo>=</mo> <msqrt> <mrow> <mn>1</mn> <mo>+</mo> <msup> <mi>y</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msup> </mrow> </msqrt> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3EF1@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. Let S be the shaded region bounded by the two graphs and the x-axis. The line and the curve intersect at point P.
content.question: Use the polar equation given in part (c) to set up an integral expression with respect to the polar angle θ that represents the area of S.

frqParts.text: Use the polar equation given in part (c) to set up an integral expression with respect to the polar angle θ that represents the area of S.

unit.text: 9: Parametric Equations, Polar Coordinates, and Vector-Valued Functions

topic.text: 9.8: (BC ONLY) Find the Area of a Polar Region or the Area Bounded by a Single Polar Curve

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Apply an appropriate mathematical definition, theorem, or test.
